misconceptions.title: Common Health Misconceptions
misconceptions.subtitle: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§Æ ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§‡§´‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Å
misconceptions.description: Learn the truth about common health myths in rural India. Tap each card to flip and discover the facts.

didYouKnow.title: Did You Know? / ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§™ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç?
didYouKnow.text: Most health problems in rural areas can be prevented with simple knowledge and basic healthcare practices.

cta.title: Stay Informed, Stay Healthy
cta.subtitle: ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§®‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§Ç
cta.text: Share these facts with your family and friends. Knowledge saves lives.

items.fact: Vaccines protect you and your family from serious diseases.
items.tip: Vaccines contain weakened or inactive parts of a disease that trigger your body's immune response. They are safe and prevent serious illnesses like polio, measles, and tetanus.

items.fact: They should eat nutritious food for their health and baby's growth.
items.tip: Pregnant women need extra nutrients including iron, folic acid, and calcium. Eating balanced meals helps ensure a healthy pregnancy and baby development.

items.myth: Boiled water is bad for health.
items.fact: Boiling kills germs and makes water safe to drink.
items.tip: Boil water for at least 10-15 minutes to remove harmful bacteria, viruses, and parasites. This simple method prevents waterborne diseases like diarrhea and cholera.

items.myth: Fever should not be treated with cold water.
items.fact: Cold compress helps reduce fever safely.
items.tip: Use a clean cloth soaked in room temperature or slightly cool water on the forehead. This helps bring down body temperature naturally. Avoid ice-cold water as it may cause shivering.

items.myth: Only city hospitals provide good treatment.
items.fact: Government Primary Health Centres (PHCs) also give free, quality care.
items.tip: PHCs provide free medicines, vaccinations, maternal care, and basic treatments. ASHA workers and ANMs are trained to help with common health issues. Visit your nearest PHC for checkups.

items.myth: Eating papaya during pregnancy causes miscarriage.
items.fact: Ripe papaya is safe and full of vitamins.
items.tip: Fully ripe papaya is excellent for pregnant women as it contains Vitamin A and C. Avoid raw or semi-ripe papaya as it contains latex which might be harmful.

items.myth: Mental illness is caused by evil spirits.
items.fact: It is a medical condition treatable by doctors.
items.tip: Mental health issues are brain disorders, not supernatural events. Psychiatrists and psychologists can treat them with therapy and medication.

items.fact: Antibiotics only kill bacteria, not viruses.
items.tip: Colds and flu are caused by viruses. Taking antibiotics for them won't help and can increase antibiotic resistance. Rest and hydration are best.

items.myth: Men don't need to worry about family planning.
items.fact: Family planning is a shared responsibility.
items.tip: Men play a crucial role. Condoms are a safe, effective method of contraception that involves men and also protects against sexually transmitted infections.

items.myth: Drinking less water reduces swelling during pregnancy.
items.fact: Drinking enough water actually helps reduce swelling.
items.tip: Staying hydrated helps flush out waste and prevents fluid retention. Pregnant women should drink 8-10 glasses of water daily.

items.fact: Glasses correct vision and reduce eye strain.
items.tip: Glasses help you see clearly and stop your eyes from working too hard. They do not weaken your eyes; refusing to wear them might cause headaches.

items.myth: Dengue mosquitoes only bite at night.
items.fact: They primarily bite during the day.
items.tip: Aedes mosquitoes, which spread dengue, are most active early morning and late afternoon. Use repellents and wear full sleeves even during the day.

items.myth: Newborns should be given honey or water first.
items.fact: Only breastmilk should be given for 6 months.
items.tip: Breastmilk contains all the water and nutrients a baby needs. Honey can be dangerous for infants under 1 year due to botulism risk.

items.myth: TB is hereditary and cannot be cured.
items.fact: TB is infectious but completely curable.
items.tip: Tuberculosis spreads through air when someone coughs. It is not genetic. With a full course of DOTS treatment, it can be cured completely.

items.myth: Snake bites should be cut and sucked.
items.fact: Never cut or suck the wound; go to hospital.
items.tip: Immobilize the bitten limb and keep the patient calm. Cutting or sucking wastes time and can cause infection. Antivenom at a hospital is the only cure.

myths.title: Explore Health Myths
myths.desc: Discover the truth about common health misconceptions. Tap interactive cards to learn facts that can save lives.

impact.title: The Difference We Hope to Make
impact.desc: Every person who learns to check symptoms online, every family that finds a nearby clinic, every elderly person who books their first telemedicine appointment‚Äîthat's progress. Small steps toward making healthcare accessible to everyone, everywhere.

story.title: Why We Built This
story.p1: We're a small team of students who've seen family members struggle to access basic healthcare. Whether it was a grandmother who couldn't read her prescription or a cousin who had to travel 50 kilometers for a simple checkup‚Äîwe've all experienced the gap.
story.p2: During a college hackathon, we decided to stop talking about the problem and actually do something. We're not healthcare experts or professional developers‚Äîjust people who believe technology should make life easier, not harder.
story.p3: This is our small attempt to bridge that gap. To make healthcare feel a little less distant for people who need it most.

vision.title: Our Vision for the Future
vision.p1: We imagine a world where your location doesn't determine your access to healthcare. Where a farmer in a remote village can video-call a doctor as easily as someone in a city. Where health literacy isn't a privilege, but a right everyone can exercise from their phone.
vision.p2: One app, one village, one person at a time‚Äîwe're working toward that future.

tips.title: Basic First Aid Tips
list: Stay calm and keep the patient comfortable
Do not move the patient if there's a serious injury
Stop any bleeding by applying gentle pressure
Keep the patient warm with a blanket
Note down what happened and when it occurred
